awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Reshaping Mathematical Identity by Valuing Creativity in Calculus
awd_abstract_narration:
In this collaborative project, the University of La Verne and the University of Oklahoma will develop, assess, and share teaching strategies to better prepare students for STEM careers. According to recent reports from IBM and the World Economic Forum, creativity is one of the most sought-after skills in STEM occupations. Thus, helping undergraduates develop creativity could support the future success of our nation's STEM workforce. Creativity in mathematics is an under-researched but very significant area of study in undergraduate students' mathematical learning. This collaborative project will study creativity and its relationship to students' identity as mathematicians and confidence.  The study will investigate the effects of incorporating mathematical creativity exercises into an introductory calculus course. This course is a prime target for creativity training, since passing calculus is required for most students who wish to major in STEM fields.  The implementation of professional development and studying its effects on both faculty and students will result in recommendations for university instructors to enhance mathematical creativity early in students' STEM undergraduate careers. 

The project has two goals: To develop and use an existing Creativity-in-Progress Rubric (CPR) on Problem Solving to explicitly value creativity in Calculus I and to investigate the effects of valuing creativity using the CPR on Problem Solving on students' identities as mathematicians. This work will be done through multiple implementations at various institutions, including the collaborating universities and the University of Central Oklahoma, the University of Northern Colorado Greely, the University of New Haven, and California State Polytechnic University Pomona. The project will investigate how instructors:  a) explicitly value creativity through their various uses of the CPR on Problem Solving; b) assess creativity-based tasks; and c) attend to students' affect throughout the course. A part of the project is situated within Hispanic-Serving Institutions, providing the potential to further identify effectiveness of creativity-centered pedagogies on Latinx students and potentially broaden the impact of this project. The intersection of teaching strategies for creativity and equity will be the focus of an additional exploration. Through developing students' creativity, the project aims to build equity in the mathematics classroom, with the ultimate goal of building equity in the STEM workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Since mathematicians state that creativity is crucial in their work, we believe that while teaching mathematics, one should engage students in valued mathematical actions such as taking risks and making connections that would lead to creativity in mathematics. We focus our attention on Calculus I–a course that plays a critical role in students’ persistence in STEM programs–because creativity is often overlooked there. 

Learners bring their prior experiences into the classroom which influences how they learn mathematics, who should learn it, and how they feel about learning it; this impacts students’ persistence in mathematics and other STEM fields. Our research is grounded in exploring teaching practices with an objective of fostering mathematical creativity in Calculus 1 and measuring effects of those teaching practices, including how students and faculty reshape their mathematical identities. 

We developed and utilized the Creativity-in-Progress Rubric (CPR) on Problem Solving to explicitly value creativity in Calculus I. We designed creativity-fostering  tasks and studied instructor participants’ use of innovative learning opportunities centered around utilizing CPR on Problem Solving.

Overall, in three years, 14 instructors completed the intervention, and over 400 students were impacted at 12 schools. Through the life of the project, we’ve shown the following gains:

  • identifying research-based features of creativity-fostering tasks in Calculus. Additionally, the researchers developed a framework that guides practitioners in their design process of such tasks. The qualitative data indicated that the implementation of these tasks through specific teaching actions (see below) in the classroom had a positive impact on students’ affect such as enjoyment and comfort with mathematics. Quantitatively, our results provide some support for the impact of teaching actions on mathematics such as assigning creativity-fostering tasks on students’ learning behaviors and affect. 

  • Broadening definitions of mathematical creativity to either incorporate students’ perspectives in previous definitions, or to add new considerations when thinking about math creativity. Students’ perspectives have been traditionally not as well-considered as instructors’ or experts’ perspectives, and our findings add to the math creativity discourse.

  • Changes in participant instructor perspectives. For example, our instructors show changes in 1) their task selection process to pick fewer more thoughtful examples 2) perspectives of mathematical creativity–that it can be taught rather than being a innate trait 3) the view of the online professional development sessions–they value the community built around student learning 4) the priorities of covering all the content versus giving students time to ask questions and make connections 5) alignment of learning outcomes to class activities to assessments.

  • Uncovered instructor teaching actions students report as not only fostering creativity, but also positively impacting students’ enjoyment of and confidence in doing mathematics: 1) Prompt and Encourage Different Approaches or Divergent Thinking 2) De-emphasize Correctness in Class 3) Attend to Social/Emotional Part of Learning 4) Challenge Students with Open-ended, Real-world, Application Problems. These teaching actions fall into four main categories: Task-Related, Teaching-Centered, Active Learning, and Holistic Teaching, which suggests fostering creativity is possible through a variety of overall teaching methods.

  • Exploring how mathematical creativity intersect with the various identities of students through their mathematics autobiographies: 1) Proving self to others - students of color/female students attempting to show their creativity in order to prove their worth to their peers 2) Upbringing - students’ creativity/lack of creativity due to their cultural upbringing 3) Being a part of an academic program or community - students’ sense of creativity is tied participation in the STEM community 4) Through other students’ identities - students’ sense of creativity is tied to shared identity with their peers. 5) Through instructors’ identities -  students’ sense of creativity is tied to instructor identity.

  • Observed that the association between post-test mathematics learning behaviors and teaching actions is stronger in the experimental condition than it is in the control condition after controlling for participants' pre-test scores. Our results suggested that in the experimental condition, one unit increase in teaching actions is associated with a .56 unit increase in the post-test mathematics learning behaviors, whereas it is only associated with a .09 unit increase in the control condition. However, we did not observe such differential associations across conditions for the mathematics learning affect and teaching actions.
